Geoengineering is not a horrible idea, nor is the "crisis" nearly as bad as many make it out to be. It's merely another problem to be solved, not the "end of the world". Many have used it as an excuse to extort political power, trying to create panic to profit from it, rather than addressing it like responsible adults. Solar shades filtering out a few percent of select wavelengths of sunlight is within our current technology and probably a much better option than messing with the atmosphere since it's easily undone if it goes wrong.

This isn't as globally caused in the way it once was as many western countries have massively reduced their carbon output. The main culprits are currently developing nations like India and China; understandable in some cases while inexcusable in others. Yes, older developed nations have their fair share of blame, but it took far longer for them to mature than it does a country starting today. Instead of centuries, it takes mere decades with new technology mitigating many of the environmental issues of the past.

Imagining a worst case scenario is entertaining, but not very useful when realistic projections are needed to find solutions.

Of course other means of sequestration like regenerative agriculture DAC and ocean capture will also be needed.

Biochar is the most promising form of sequestration alongside regenerative agriculture that I have found.

DAC can pair with biogas and H2 burned in existing natural gas power plants. Rather than direct air it is more carbon capture sequestration, but it makes sense to use carbon neutral fuels that pair with carbon capture to make them carbon negative. Direct Air Capture is very difficult with the diffuse air and it is so much cost in capital to capture air. You might as well find a higher concentration of CO2 from CO2 neutral fuels like biogas from anaerobic digesters that can also pair with making biochar from the waste heat of the thermal power plant. The Aircraft. Four C-130H aircraft are modified to perform aerial application. Modifications consist mostly of ULV (Ultra-Low Volume) and LV (Low Volume) wing line installation and electrical modifications.

Spray System. The MASS is built by Lockheed/Conair. One of the major design criteria of the MASS was that it had to be a "roll-on/roll-off" system allowing the aircraft to be reconfigured for spray or airlift in under an hour. To accommodate the Roll-on/Roll-off design, the full MASS is designed in 3 modules, each attached to modified standard (463L) aircraft cargo pallets. The operators console, pumps, catwalks, and cradles for flush and chemical tanks are all secured to these modified pallets. The pallets lock into the C-130's dual rail system. Once the MASS is loaded, interconnecting plumbing and electrical circuits tie the MASS modules together. To contain any spillage of spray materials, a 1.5" lip (drip pan) surrounds the pallets. The dry weight of the MASS is ca. 10,500 lbs."

Where are the official sources that state that a certain number of people (worldwide?) will sicken and possibly die as a result of the spraying? In other words, what internal studies have been done on the health issues and who carried them out?

WHO (World Health Organization) carried out most of the studies. Other nations have carried their own research on the matter. Some have said the ill effects will be minimal – along the lines of a million or so, while others have found the numbers to be far higher – 3 to 4 billion.

Some of the organizations include the CDC and independent labs. We are dealing with a situation where the amount of contamination is estimated to be far higher than what would normally take place but is far lower than historical instances of industrial contamination. This is important to note, the only real history we have with barium/aluminum/titanium etc. contamination is through factory workers, miners, etc, who receive a far greater dosage of the material than what is to be experienced by the populace under the Shield.

The amount of spray is very small compared to the volume of the space that is covered. Most of the harmful chemicals that are used are being dissipated over vast areas. Near coastal regions the fall out is not reaching land at all, but is being carried out to the oceans. The addition of polymers to make the material remain suspended in the air longer means that less material is being used.

Today the material used and its application is nothing like in the early days when it was sprayed in greater quantities and settling far faster to be inhaled by all.

The accepted Estimated Casualties (from WHO) is 2 billion over the course of 6 decades. The majority will be either the elderly, or those who are prone to respiratory problems. These numbers are based on the current estimates of the general health of the population, the average age and the occurrence of respiratory problems as a health issue. All are estimates since there are no solid numbers to work with.

In reality, geoengineering is the only reasonable solution. Carbon neutrality is and always will be a pipe dream, the truth is to stop climate change radical changes to our economy have to happen _right now_. Literally anything less will result in irrevocable damage. The only problem is, those changes would harm the economy enough that we're talking about an equivalent loss in life anyway. The economy is more than just 'more money so we can be richer', it's production, logistics, and consumption.

We don't have the production in lithium to replace fossil fuel vehicles with battery powered. Even if you made them all illegal today, you would be talking about halting shipping of things like food and medicine across the country. Outlawing fossil fuel energy production would cause electricity costs to skyrocket, to the point that anyone even close to the poverty line would be unable to afford it and vital infrastructure would go dark.

If you wanted to do all of this with minimal loss of life, the only option is to nationalize every production industry. Otherwise, profits will drop so hard that those businesses will just fire 90% of their employees and move on to other industries that generate more profit (as large corporations always do when the economy tanks) while small businesses would be left to die.

And all of those points are just about first world countries like the US and Europe, the loss of life in third-world countries, and transitionary/recovering economies like India, Russia, and China would be in the hundreds of millions, perhaps even edging into the billions. As those countries industrialize (or in the case of Russia, recover production), they require cheap, plentiful energy and logistics, and lots of it. This is why China and India are the greatest polluters in the world, _they literally do not have the economic means to switch yet_.

To get third-world countries and developing/recovering economies to switch, would either require a miracle or military force. Either way, the loss of life in these countries would be far- far greater than in first world nations.

The thing is, it is never just about climate change. Thinking all major ecological problems on earth solely result from the greenhouse effect is reductionistic, short-sighted and thus dangerous. At the same time, it always ends in the tragedy of the commons: Nobody feeling responsible enough to take necessary measures. Policy should invest into local measures which benefit global climate as much as they benefit local ecosystems. Synergies, not tradeoffs. Integrated water management for example: It is important to make water run slower towards the sea again so the soil is wetter and better at keeping more. This results in resilient vegetation, whose demise would otherwise set free lots of CO2. Of course we need to get shift away from fossil fuels, but it is about much more than just renewable energy. Unfortunately, the climate debate has taken on a life of its own, making it look like climate change was the only ecological problem in the world.

It's videos like this why I can't take this channel seriously, it's just well presented drivel.
- Warmer water means more sea life, not less. Where do you see more vibrant sea life? At the caribbean or the arctic sea? High CO2 and temperature were crucial in the cambrian explosion without which we wouldn't exist;
- Atmospheric sulfuric acid is one of the primary causes of acid rain, purposefully creating it is a terrible idea;
- Regular planes with payload capacity to deliver gases cannot reach the stratosphere as the air is far too thin to allow subsonic flight, only the Concorde has both the ability to (barely) reach the stratosphere while also have a relevant payload capacity, and we know they're not remotely cheap;
- Sulfur dioxide is heavier than air, it's not going to magically stay in the stratosphere;
- Carbonic acid is very weak and the solubility of CO2 decreases as temperature increases, that means a runaway ocean acidification through atmospheric CO2 is not possible. However, continuously increasing the sulfuric acid in the atmosphere could increase it;

You are being rather closed-minded on geoengineering “not being a solution to climate change”, but I like that you are bringing it up, because it truly is THE solution to climate change, not reducing CO2 in the air.

You dismiss the ideas other than literal chem trails (which the conspiracy theorists will immediately spot and which threaten the possibility of acid rain and termination shot) far too quickly, for the real solution is the construction of that mirror at the L1 Lagrange point that is 2000 km in diameter and which also reduces the sunlight hitting the Earth by 1%. This is because there is no termination shock since once it is placed there with automated systems with their own non-Earth maintenance (using in-situ resource utilization on the Moon) schedules, it never goes away, and it does not heat up the Stratosphere.

It will also have a trivial price (the cost of the first autonomous self-replicating robots (i.e. factories which can build every piece of themselves from the regolith on the moon) being placed on the moon), and will not face the problems of collective action which will stop the world from switching away from fossil fuels (the problem not being the scapegoat of rich people trading the future away, but in the clear necessity of these fuels to people who are barely making ends meet right now).

The only problem that more CO2 in the atmosphere would cause at that point in time is just the bleaching of coral, but that is far easier to deal with by just speeding up the process of natural selection by using the technology we have today to edit the genes of the creatures making the coral to be resistant to higher CO2 levels. This is completely consistent with nature (don’t go into that knee-jerk reaction of saying “why are you advocating for GMOs?”) because throughout the history of the Earth there have been many times where the CO2 level of the oceans was far higher than now and the creatures there adapted just as well, so providing these modifications is doing the exact same thing (using the very same process that DNA gets changed in nature) but targeted in a way that eliminates the side-effects that natural selection has that have always entailed vast quantities of unnecessary suffering among creatures doomed to die without our intervention.

tldr; the “protection of nature” arguments in many of the comments and this video that stake against fundamental geo-engineering principles are disingenuous and close-minded with respect to what we can actually do!

I live near Mount Pinatubo. My dad watched the houses by the river as they were engulfed by the pyroclastic flow. The ashfall collapsed so many rooftops, including ours.

Woah, woah, woah. That is a HORRIBLE idea from thermodynamics perspective. You DO NOT want to add more junk to air at high altitudes. There is a reason air is very cold at altitude. As air rises, it expands and cools. Conversely, downwards air currents heat up. A pressure differential leads to an almost fixed temperature differential. For relevant altitudes, differential with surface is about 75K. If we spray an aerosol at high altitude, that's where thermal radiation equilibrium is established. If atmosphere was perfectly transparent in all wavelengths, average temperature on Earth's surface would have been about 255K. If the aerosol has similar albedo and leads to temperatures of 255K at altitude of aerosol, which is average of 330K at the surface. That's guaranteed death for all land life.

Current mean temperature on Earth is 287K. To have aerosol be helping, temperature at altitude where aerosol is sprayed has to be bellow 210K or so. That's almost impossible to achieve for an aerosol. The radiation equilibrium temperature is controlled by relationship of 1 - albedo and emissivity in infrared. To achieve temperature of 210K or bellow, the ratio (1-a)/e must be less than 0.58. For particles less than 10 microns in diameter, that's basically impossible, and for these less than 100 microns very difficult, because you're effectively trying to make something that's really, really good at absorbing IR and is also very, very reflective in visible light. You'd need some way to make sure more light is reflected up than scattered horizontally.

Volcanic eruptions are a horrible example. The short-term effect is cooling, sure, because less sunlight at the surface, but all this time, upper atmosphere is heating up. That takes a while, but once it warms up, it starts heating up lower atmosphere and the surface. Long term effect of more dust in upper atmosphere is ALWAYS heating. If sulfuric acid haze was good at keeping a planet cool, Venus would be an arctic wasteland.

"The scariest thing about this proposition is that models suggest that many of the people who could well be most harmed by these technologies are already disproportionately vulnerable to the impacts of climate change. Imagine this: North America decides to send sulfur into the stratosphere to reduce the intensity of the sun, in the hopes of saving its corn crops — despite the real possibility of triggering droughts in Asia and Africa. In short, geoengineering would give us (or some of us) the power to exile huge swaths of humanity to sacrifice zones with a virtual flip of the switch.

The geopolitical ramifications are chilling. Climate change is already making it hard to know whether events previously understood as “acts of God” (a freak heat wave in March or a Frankenstorm on Halloween) still belong in that category. But if we start tinkering with the earth’s thermostat — deliberately turning our oceans murky green to soak up carbon and bleaching the skies hazy white to deflect the sun — we take our influence to a new level. A drought in India will come to be seen — accurately or not — as a result of a conscious decision by engineers on the other side of the planet. What was once bad luck could come to be seen as a malevolent plot or an imperialist attack.

[...}

Mr. George and his ocean-altering experiment provides an opportunity for public debate about an issue essentially absent during the election cycle: What are the real solutions to climate change? Wouldn’t it be better to change our behavior — to reduce our use of fossil fuels — before we begin fiddling with the planet’s basic life-support systems?

Unless we change course, we can expect to hear many more reports about sun-shielders and ocean fiddlers like Mr. George, whose iron dumping exploit did more than test a thesis about ocean fertilization: it also tested the waters for future geoengineering experiments. And judging by the muted response so far, the results of Mr. George’s test are clear: geoengineers proceed, caution be damned."

Geoengineering: Testing the Waters
By Naomi Klein
Oct. 27, 2012

Kinda unpopular opinion I think, so bear with me. Imo we shouldn't be so resilient about not changing the way we live today. I think that solving climate change is much more important than having excessively many things to spend money on. We don't need the majority of things that exist in our lives to survive (or even to live a good life), we should stop being such babies and take serious action to find solutions, even if we have to give up the luxuries of modern life for a while (or at least some of them). Climate change is our fault, we shouldn't be looking so hard to escape any punishment because we deserve it. That's why I'd much rather switch instantly to eco-friendly energy sources and give up fossil fuel completely (or keep it to an absolute minimum). I might be wrong, but without all the useless stuff that we have and could rid ourselves of, it should be possible.  And also, it won't be permanent, just until things get better and we find better solutions. I don't see any reason against this other that people are too stubborn to go back in development a little, it may be our nature. But I still think it would be the quickest and best solution. The actual problem is with the people. The big guys don't want to lose their oil money and the little guys wouldn't trust a leader proposing such a drastic measure (also wouldn't like losing their comfortable lifestyle for a while). Also, some people think that if it won't have grave consequences in their lifetime then climate change is not a top priority. If we could just all agree to do this as a whole, for OUR good in the future, it would be best, but that's a bit too idealistic. This is something I've been thinking of so if you have found a flaw in anything I said please tell me, I'm really curious about what people might think about something like this.

I notice this really only covers one of the major geoengineering or climate engineering proposals the one that in my opinion probably has some of the worst consequences if it goes wrong. But there are others the two biggest categories are solar radiation management and carbon dioxide removal. I don't really know of anybody I have read or talked to who thinks we should just use one of these techniques to the exclusion of others. For solar radiation management I can easily see a combination of troposphere surface and upper atmosphere based Solutions helping get the temperature issue under control quickly. Perhaps the stratospheric sulfate aerosols to get it under control really quickly then we build surface based mirrors and Marine Cloud brightening systems to get it under control over a slightly longer time with less severe consequences. All of that while we get CO2 under control through things like ocean alkalinization, ocean iron fertilization, growing more trees, creating biochar. I've watched the sky for almost 60 years.  Sometimes I would see short contrails following and dissipating behind jets...it wasn't an every day occurrence.  About thirteen years ago where I lived, planes started leaving contrails that stretched from horizon to horizon, And the trails turned into ugly manmade clouds.  Now there are often days when it's hard to look up because the sun is behind these fake clouds, and brightly illuminating them, making the sky---not just the sun, but the sky---blindingly bright white.  And I regularly see "sundogs" which were extremely rare before, and occasionally on very bright days there's a big ugly halo around the sun.  Downvote this and call me childish names if you want, but I'm certain of what I'm saying.  And if you take the time each day to note what is happening in the sky, you will see it as well.

In 1980 Smallpox was deemed eradicated from the whole world. This was made possible by a global effort by the World Health Organisation.
This proves that the Worlds governments can unite together and more importantly work together to solve a crisis.
It seems that the biggest problem we face with climate change is ‘Big Money’, that is to say those that are financially better off with things staying as they are.
To combat this all governments should put forth thier own scientists to work alongside scientists from around the world . These scientists should be given the ultimate power to implement whatever changes they see fit . A Global effort worked within the communication problems of the 70’s , nowadays it should be a breeze .
Right now you may be thinking of all sorts of reasons why that couldn’t work , this is exactly what ‘Big Money’ relies on, by convincing us all not to try, what we should all be thinking is , yes there is problems with this idea but nothing that we couldn’t sort out .
Lastly I’m getting old, I’ve lived through many hard times and disasters yet we prevail, climate change isn’t something that will effect me as I will be dead and gone , my concern is for those generations after me that do have to live through it, if a person like myself is concerned then the younger generation should be bloody terrified .
My last point is this , to those that will read this and simply say ,
“Well it was generations before us that started the problem” ,
Well ofcourse your right but you are thinking in the wrong direction , it’s not about who created the problem as that answer serves no purpose , I say to you the only question should be ,
How do we fix this .
If the whole world unites to ask the same question then we would be well on our way to a solution, sadly though some countries still choose to ignore the obvious which is , it doesn’t matter wether climate change is mans fault or a natural cycle , it is still going to detriment the whole world and our way of life . If we don’t do something .

Ocean acidification is a more significant threat than heating the atmosphere. Humans are REALLY good at adapting. Brainless organisms that have been in stasis for millenia are not good at adapting. Especially when their lives depend on too much symbyosis. The better alternative to combat ocean acidification is the one that directly removes dissolved CO2 from seawater, namely the last of the three mentioned here, Ocean Fertilization. Unlike the other options mentioned ocean fertilization takles the problem at its source by fixing the equilibrium equation of the carbon cycle. If we've already done alot of higher flowrate out of the lithosphere we have to fix equilibrium by accelerating flowrate into the lithosphere and the main way that happens is by ocean floor deposition. Many organisms depend on this part of the carbon cycle and serve to redirect carbon back up, to combat this reaction we can do one of the things we do best, overfish. The overfishing would specifically need to target the species that carry carbon back up, like bristlemouths (extremely high population).

Falun Gong practitioner Mr. Liu talks about the CCP's persecution.

The focus of Mr. Hill's investigation was whether the CCP is still conducting live organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners or other prisoners of conscience. He interviewed Falun Gong practitioners Ms. Yang and Mr. Liu, who were incarcerated in China for their belief. Both practitioners talked about how they suffered as a result of the CCP's persecution. Both said that they were periodically forced to undergo medical examinations.

Ms. Yang recalled that in 2005 she was detained in a Beijing labor camp for 18 months. She said, “They checked my body every three months. They took all these Falun Gong practitioners to the hospital. The hospital belongs to the police department and is very near the labor camp. The medical examinations included X-rays of our chests, liver examinations, ultrasound B scans, and blood tests.”

Mr. Liu was released last year. He said, “I was subjected to medical examinations several times while I was imprisoned. Blood was collected. All Falun Gong practitioners are forced to renounce their belief. If you do not yield, the prison guards beat your arms, legs, and buttocks, but not your vital organ areas.”

In the program BBC Impact, Mr. Hill explained to Philippa Thomas why the CCP wants to persecute prisoners of conscience and Falun Gong. The CCP considers anyone outside the control of the state and any minority groups to be threats.

When the number of Falun Gong practitioners reached 100 million people in 1999, the CCP viewed them as a great threat. First they were slandered by the Communist Party, and then they were detained on a large scale.

The United Nations Special Rapporteur on Torture noted that Falun Gong practitioners who adhere to peace and faith were being tortured in detention centers.

Mr. Hill referred to the independent investigation report by David Kilgour, Canadian former Secretary of State for Asia; David Matas, Canadian human rights lawyer; and Ethan Gutmann, a senior reporter from the U.S. They were interviewed in the BBC program, “Who to Believe?” They reminded viewers that the CCP persecutes prisoners of conscience not for money but to carry out cruel genocide.

Mr. Matas said, “The death penalty number has been decreasing in China but the transplant volume is going up. There is the volume without any other obviously explained sources besides prisoners of conscience. There is a huge arbitrary detention of prisoners of conscience in the hundreds of thousands in China.”

He continued, “Short waiting time. People come when they want and get organs almost immediately, which meant somebody was killed for their organs.”

David Kilgour said, “If you are considered an enemy of the state, then your life is valueless. That's the problem. For the Tibetans, Uighur, and some house Christians, especially Falun Gong, there are lots of reports.”

Ethan Gutmann said, “It's about (how) the state destroys its enemies. The money is an incentive for this to happen.”

Mr. Hill summarized his investigation by saying, “We will not stop doubting that the CCP is still conducting organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience. The huge difference between the numbers that the CCP officials claim from organ donors and the actual organ transplants. (In 2015, the CCP claimed to stop using the organs procured as a result of the death penalty. Current organ transplants rely mainly on organs from patients who have died in intensive care units.) Due to the lack of transparency, the source of organs in China's transplant tourism market remains a mystery. Therefore, we will not stop doubting that the CCP is still conducting organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience.”

Interesting that only "world governments" are mentioned as "failing to adequately respond to climate change," and while Kgt isn't saying Stratospheric Aerosol Injection is the ideal response to climate change, they are choosing to discuss this topic now. Why?

World governments (i.e. governments large enough) are unable to implement the solutions to climate change because energy infrastructure is privatized and the technology they'd adapt to combat climate change isn't financially advantageous relative to what private industry wants. That is to say, the loss of mining/drilling, transportation, refinement and processing removes many points of investment, reduces the value of property/ equipment used and ends the need for the employees risking their lives to make it all happen. Furthermore, it grants a significant sense of importance on the individuals and families who own the capitol.

However, an alternative (or stopgap) that utilizes and necessitates large investments in capitol (e.g. planes, runways, chemical plants) similar to what is already expected is something our financial masters would prefer, especially if their well lobbied governments will give them money to make it happen. Furthermore, it allows fossil fuel companies to extend their overspent grace period of getting the fuck out (if any even had the sense to do so and weren't just stalling for time and opportunity).

SAI is a solution that appeals to billionaires and billion dollar industry, which allows them to stay relevant while maximizing profit, gets them good PR, and doesn't solve climate change (kinda like fracking). So naturally they're going to push it and use preexisting platforms to do the pushing.

) Canadian Parliament Member Garnett Genuis made a motion for Senate Bill 240 on the House floor on Tuesday. The bill, an act to amend the Criminal Code and the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (trafficking in human organs), was thus first read in the House of Commons.


MP Garnett Genuis

In a statement made on Monday, MP Genuis said, “For 10 years, members of Parliament have been trying to pass legislation to address the scourge of international organ trafficking. My colleague, the member for Etobicoke Centre, as well as former Liberal MP and justice minister Irwin Cotler, both presented bills on this issue in the previous Parliament. None have passed until this point though.”

Genuis commended the work of the Senate, and Senator Ataullahjan in particular, for getting Bill S-240 through the Senate and perfecting the bill.

“This is further than this bill has ever made it before, but it is critical that we pass this legislation in this Parliament, so we do not have to start all over again.” said Genuis. “I hope we will finally be able to get this done in this Parliament.”

The bill has two key points. First, it makes it a criminal offence for Canadians to go abroad for an organ for which there is no consent by a donor. Secondly, it designates individuals inadmissible to Canada if they have been involved in this heinous practice.

While China's state-sanctioned organ harvesting is targeted by this legislation, Genuis said the bill has been written to address potential future problems in other countries.

“I think that every Member understands that certainly the biggest problem in this respect by far are the actions of the Chinese Government,” said Genuis.

“This Bill will make it illegal for somebody to go abroad to receive an organ for which there is no consent,” he said. “We hear of cases where someone might book a heart transplant in China and they are booking a heart transplant a month in advance knowing that a particular organ will be available on a particular day and that obviously cannot happen, but for the killing of that person at a scheduled time before the transplant takes place.”

Genuis said that while the bill does not solve the whole problem, “it addresses the possibility of Canadians being complicit in this problem and it increases the international pressure.”

Regarding the likelihood of the bill making it to the finish line, the lawmaker said, “I am fairly confident that even if the Cabinet were to oppose this, there will be enough individual Liberal Members of Parliament breaking ranks and we would get it passed. The question is timing. And hopefully the government will support it. So we will have unanimous support in the House to move the Bill along very quickly.”

g) October 18, 2018, marked the 12th annual EU Anti-Trafficking Day to raise awareness of the atrocities of human trafficking. In conjunction with this important date, Falun Dafa practitioners in Greece held an event in Athens on October 20 to draw attention to the trafficking of vital organs taken from living Falun Dafa practitioners being persecuted by the Chinese communist regime.

Falun Dafa (also called Falun Gong) is a traditional mind-body cultivation practice. It has been brutally suppressed by the Chinese Communist Party since 1999 in a campaign of persecution that amounts to genocide. Falun Dafa practitioners and other prisoners of conscience, including Tibetans, Christians, and Uighurs, have been targeted for their organs in extrajudicial killings sanctioned by the state.




The Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs encourages activities centered around the October 18 commemoration and supported the practitioners' event.

The event was held on Syntagma Square in the center of Athens. Passersby were shocked to learn about the killing of Falun Dafa practitioners in China for their organs, and many had a hard time believing the brutality carried out in Chinese prisons.

Practitioners told them about the investigations that have taken place and the non-governmental organizations working to stop these crimes. They also mentioned laws being enacted in European countries and around the world to ban involvement in organ trafficking in China.

Isn't the ability and knowledge to do geoengineering already an act of geoengineering? We know our current affects on our planet, and we know their source: so in a sense, removing the fingerprints of humanity is itself a form of human interference. I don't think with current knowledge any course of action can be argued as "less invasive" or more "natural" - our ability to know and our ability to choose means all of them are form of anthropocentrism.

What is called natural is merely a form of action that relies more on the planets metabolism cycles as a source for change, in enviroment humans allocate away from their most direct impact - it still is something humans 'allow' and monitor, so while it is better than direct and active manipulation, it still is something humans do.

We can not point at any part of the planet and say "that is not humanity's responsibility". The places void of human impact are so few and marginal, that their discovery is on scale a huge change for them: even when done in most subtle, noninvasive way.

So both digging up and releasing and it's antithesis, capturing and reducing CO2 are forms of geoengineering. We know what we are doing and that is enough. We can not dance around the responsibility in either way:

we either accept our anthropocentric world, or we forget science and knowledge of the world.

I’ve got a better idea; how about we leave the planet alone. It’s doing fine (it can do fine on its own). It can recover what we’ve done so long as we stop making it worse.

Please, for the love of god (or whatever) let’s just stop interfering with how we ‘think’ the planet should exist.

Obviously the solution is incredibly complex; but if we just fixed a few things such as; redesigning cities and countries(specifically the American reliance on automobiles) so that we could walk, or use public transport. Also focus more on a reduction society (forget recycle and reuse), as the first ‘R’ is far more important and effective than the other two.

So stop consuming unnecessary garbage such as buying a brand new phone every year. Please stop that.

I could keep going on about hundreds of other things we can do however, the overall summary is let’s do less. Let’s stop trying to save the planet and let it heal on its own.

But most importantly of all to achieve this; STOP DESTROYING EVERYTHING in the first place.

Fires, floods and storms are normal. Let’s please stop the fear mongering about what’s the new ‘record’ in regards to things we’ve only been reliably measuring for 50-150 years MAX. When we’re looking at the grand scale of things on a timeline of billions of years; I don’t care if yesterday was the hottest day ‘on record’. When our records are pathetic and meaningless.

I know it may be hard to accept this truth; but koalas dying in bushfires is natural. It is not our purpose to stop every natural disaster and save all the animals in existence.

Before humans existed, natural disasters had always occurred and species have gone extinct far more than we can even imagine.

You people have been attempting this ‘fear people into reaction’ strategy for decades, right from the beginning. Has it worked? No.

Please try a new approach.

I’m tired of the blame being placed on the average citizen, when in reality the greatest impact on the climate are large corporations.

Stop yelling at me to save the planet and make the true polluters held accountable.

As long as production continues, consumers will always consume. ‘It’s their, I want it, I’m buying it’. Such a simple mindset.

So stop the production of stuff we don’t need in the first place. The people can’t pollute if we can’t buy a car we don’t need. We can’t be wasteful if we don’t live in a society that expects us to buy new shoes or fashion accessory simply because it’s in ‘trend’.

Nobody seems to account for the 144 Btu per pound ice absorbs as it melts. Melting ice is like ice in a cooler. It helps temper the planet as it melts. When the ice is gone we will know what global warming is. As I understand it, frozen precipitation undergoes up to 5 freeze melt cycles as it falls through the atmosphere. What happens to the latent heat of fusion every time melting occurs in the process. Does some of it radiate to space? Evaporating water takes 970 Btu per pound with it into the atmosphere. What happens to the latent heat of vaporization as the water condenses and falls back to earth? Does some of that heat radiate to space? If so, precipitation is like a built in air conditioning system for the planet. Do you want to take a chance on overloading it?

Honestly this shouldn't be a backup option. We should work on doing this right now. Scientists are unsure where the runaway point is (some say as early as 1.7C). We want to stop + reverse warming before it reaches a point with any possibility of runaway. Of course, problems like the ozone layer should be fully explored before we act.

The delaying excuse argument is like saying that if we accept Jewish refugees in WWII, then that gives the nazis more incentive to kill/deport Jews. "Someone might do something bad about it" is not an excuse to not do a good thing.

Fundamentally though, something needs to be done to make it economically beneficial to tackle climate change. Everyone is well aware of the issue; we aren't acting on it because all the projected economic damage will happen long after the decision-makers are dead. Taking strikes n all is not going to change the incentivisation pattern. I'm not sure what precisely should be done, but it should be in this direction rather than making more and more excellent plans for tackling climate change that will never get implemented due to the aforementioned reasons.

All in all, though, I am glad that Kurzgesagt takes the effort to recognise geoengineering as a vital part of the solution to climate change, despite what Greta and Greenpeace may tell you.

We do need to transition those economies. People like Trump aren’t really helping matters. He frequently will avoid the question when asked about climate change and just talk about how we are managing climate change “the best in the world” right now, and not actually speak about plans to move the economy towards different energy sources. The time for fuel-based energy is dying, it has to. There’s too many poor side effects to its use and those effects are building up. However, NO energy source is ‘perfect’ for human needs/desires, NOTHING. Wind power? High cost per-yielding of energy, kills birds, only works when it’s windy out. Water? It just doesn’t produce enough energy because there aren’t very many rivers compared to the amount of land and still oceans. Solar? Still kind of expensive, only works when it’s day out, panels only work for a little while, and the materials necessary are really bad for the environment when the panels do die. Nuclear? Risky, although managed properly it should theoretically be fine. It is I believe also decently expensive. Honestly nuclear is pretty good, but the main issue is just getting businesses to use it and keeping it safe enough so that something like Chernobyl hasn’t a chance of happening. Now, let’s look at fuel. Yield? High in terms of how expensive the fuel is and the facilities can last decades. The energy-making process can happen all day long. The uses for it are many, and have been around for perhaps the longest time of any energy source, and are thus incredibly tried and true. The amount of fossil fuels also is very high in the world, so there will be no shortage any time soon. The only side effects to burning fuel as an energy source are its waste outputs. They’re bad to breathe and heat up the world, in short. Their negative effects have really only begun to become apparent in the last several decades. This is the only problem with pure capitalism. What we need is concious captalism. Very concious capitalism. We must stop using so much fossil fuels. Sooner or later, we must. For now, we must invest in new technologies and policies, regulating as they may be, to counteract the fossil fuels. There’s my speech.

I don’t think geoengineering is particularly bad at all. It’s certainly sad that we may NEED to use it on our own planet someday, but humans have been playing god since civilization was formed. The science will certainly be useful for when we one day reach levels where we can terraform entire planets to become habitable. On top of that, who’s to say we can’t alter our planet to better suit our needs anyway, even if it is never technically necessary. There isn’t much difference in anything other than scale when compared to things like cutting roads and tunnels and turning the metals and minerals inside our planet into massive structures. Some people seem to think that doing these large scale changes and advancements to our way of life somehow goes against nature, but it is important to understand that nature is not just the trees or animals, but the wind and rain, the mountains and oceans, the movement of the entire cosmos itself. We are nature too. There is nothing more natural than living and growing as you see fit. The reason global warming is bad is not that we are destroying or rebelling against nature, but because we are screwing ourselves in the long run.

This is a truly fascinating video! I presented a group presentation at my University a couple of weeks ago about Climate Change and Solar Geoengineering took centre stage. As amazing as the idea of stratospheric aerosol injection is,  I believe it is also prudent to look into the idea of Marine Cloud Brightening! A team at Harvard is looking exclusively into geoengineering and cloud brightening is a huge part of that. With what you said about coral reefs, due to the accuracy and precision of Marine Cloud Brightening you could, in theory, direct your efforts towards certain areas such as coral reefs and perhaps even the glaciers of Greenland! Hope this is interesting to someone out there and that Solar Geoengineering and Solar Radiation Management (SRM) picks up traction as quickly as is deserves to! Thank you to Kurzegesagt for being one of, if not THE best content creator on YouTube for the last several years. I would truly not know as much as I do and have such passion for my research and learning if it was not for you guys!

One thing of note is the idealistic viewpoint of "we should switch from fossil". Well, idealistic, simplistic, or just simply sterile, not really taking into consideration the humanitarian aspect of it. Ideally, yes, we should switch over to nuclear, as well as focusing more on fusion.
Humans aren't inherently greedy, but they are, as all living things, self serving and survivalists. Switching from oil, fracking, coal, and so on, would absolutely collapse industries and, take a step back with me for this one, isn't going to affect just the rich business men and women, but the thousands and thousands of workers. It's the same relative issue we have with minimum pay, where automation is replacing low skill work.
Recycling, as another example, is a highly complex issue. Windmill blades aren't being recycled but instead pile up in garbage dumps; they are recyclable but made out of a material that's very hard to break down, so you'd end up with a net loss.

Climate change isn't just an engineer or scientific problem, and you can't just oversimplify the geopolitical issues down to "people are ignorant and want the world to burn" while presenting solutions that would directly harm them and their families and loved ones, like having them be unemployed indefinitely. There is no infrastructure in place for these implementations, and I believe people are jumping way ahead of themselves. You're designing cars for roads not yet build.

Thank you for reading

I really don't think that adding sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere is a good idea. We're already doing it (sulphur impurities in petrol) and it is a major cause of acid rain, which damages plant life and makes lakes more acidic (hence killing ecosystems in them). Blocking sunlight altogether with something safer than sulphur dioxide can also be problematic. After all, the plants and algae depend on sunlight to undergo photosynthesis, and they are the only thing taking CO2 out of the atmosphere. If we diminished sunlight hitting the Earth's surface, we'll get fewer plant and algal growth, so less photosynthesis, and therefore less CO2 taken out of the air. We could just end up back at square one, if not worse. I think the kind of geoengineering we need to do is to have more green areas on the planet and we need to start as early as possible. Not only do we need to preserve existing green spaces, but we need to transform existing desert and wasteland areas into green spaces too.

Note that the aerosol effect is during the day time (less energy input), but the CO2 effect is still working at night (less energy out). This imbalance will be most extreme near the poles where we would continue to warm the poles over the long winter and then reduce the warming in the summer (we are not going to put enough aerosols up to cool back to say 1900 or even 2000 levels). It is very unclear how this will play out. For example it might affect clouds and end up reversing or amplifying our work (less cloud more sunlight in, more cloud less sunlight in).

In addition, there is the potential for a massive and predicted volcanic eruption while we’re are doing this, which could creat a shock effect of its own.

Transition from fossil fuels to what? Solar, wind, hydroelectric and other renewable apart from nuclear? They just as bad if not worse than fossil fuels once you count their pollution on materials production (they require much more regular and exotic material than fossil fuels generator in general), pollution on manufacturing, energy production per capita and and lifetime pollution (traditional fossil fuels generator like gas turbine engine have service live twice as long than even the longest live renewable and decommission solar panel are not recycle reliability enough as far as I know). The worst part of it is pale in comparison to those factors, which is their terribly unreliable power generation capability because their power generation relying on whims of fate regarding perfect condition of nature.

That is why I wholeheartedly against renewable energy that are not more reliable than fossil fuels (geothermal and nuclear are the only one that I believe can be at least as reliable as fossil fuels, but geothermal have geological constraint while the world haven't embrace nuclear yet even when their track record are proven to be impressively good compared to other methods).

REJECT MODERNITY
The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human being to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

Climate on earth is an incredibly complex and chaotic system. Any attempt of geo-engineering will likely to produce unexpected consequences that is almost impossible to predict (this is the case even with the best possible model, the prediction error will grow with time exponentially, see chaos theory, this is also the reason weather forecast over a week is likely to be inaccurate). For this reason, while we may prepare the knowledge for such geo-engineering (i.e. keep researching), performing geo-engineering will be a risk and undertaking too significant that no existing government system to this day can bear. We really need a lot to evolve, not just from the scientific perspective, and we (as human being) are no where near to be capable of such act. As alternative, it might be better to expand our living space (e.g. colonize other planets), rather than fixing the existing one. It will reduce the risk and bring us the knowledge we need (e.g. conducting geo-engineering experiments on other planets).

Here's the big problem with Geoengineering - if there is anything that Climate Change is revealing and proving in practice, is that current human societies are incapable of fully predicting long term consequences of large scale changes, and that we are unable to act promptly in response to large scale effects that comes from those changes. It's why we're in this situation in the first place.

Climate Change is a type of geoengineering, just an accidental one. It's large scale global change caused by artificial processes that have a proven significant effect on the planet that might render it uninhabitable for us.

So, what's the problem then? Well, you can imagine that, given that we had several decades of findings on Climate Change, we have demonstrable horrible effects of it happening for years, we have all the science backing and several minds around it, and significant findings and support, we still are not able to do much about it... this is likely true to any other geoengineering project. It's effectively uncontrollable, for us.

And the thing is, any geoengineering project that is aiming for faster widespread effects, will potentially also have faster widespread unpredicted side effects, of which we will likely not be able to neutralize or remediate, given our history. It doesn't matter if we put the most brilliant minds to it, just as much putting the most brilliant minds to climate change isn't solving it.

The thing is, all these proposed geoengineering projects might look mostly good in a bigger picture, or at least manageable and applicable in last case scenarios, but really - we don't know. What is being presented is an extremely optimistic and biased view, because we want to believe so much there is a simple shortcut to solving the climate crisis. So we overlook enormous logical gaps like trying to say anything we do would be anywhere close to a volcanic eruption. You know it wouldn't be. We don't even understand volcanic eruptions properly, how can people think aerosolizing chemicals into the atmostphere would have the exact same effects? Of course it won't. We don't get the entire process, and we are already taking shortcuts to say one is equal to another.

Much like it took us too long to understand the implications of pumping too much CO2, methane and other gases into the atmostphere, we don't really know, don't have the tools to accurately predict, and won't have enough time to really know every single effect that geoengineering projects can have - because the number of variables and number of potential effects are essencially infinite.

And the faster those unpredicted effects come, the less we're able to respond. Climate Change might not lead to a humanity extinction event, we're not totally sure, but geoengineering projects to counter it has several times more chances of doing it for us, because it's supposed to act faster, it's supposed to be a fast counter act to climate change. And as some people will know, the problem isn't the change, the problem is speed. What life is generally vulnerable to is fast change that surpasses it's ability to adapt.

You know how we can't even, as humans, create software that is bug and vulnerability free? Geoengineering is a problem orders of magnitude more complex. And the consequences for errors are deadly, up to mass extinction.

What would we need to do Geoengineering more safely? We'd need a perfect Earth simulation, with as many variables as possible included, if not all. If we had anything close to that, here's other stuff that we'd already be able to predict at this point - volcanic activity, weather systems, natural disasters.... climate change effects.

So, in essence, we let unqualified people mess with the Earth's atmosphere, and now we're expecting unqualified people to do a quick fix for it. I'm not trying to offend any scientist who is thinking of and working on geoengineering projects, this is just a fact. No one today is qualified enough to tell the full breadth of consequences that any proposed geoengineering project may cause. It's outside our species capabilities to do it currently. Planet Earth, if looked as a system, is so massively complex and interconnected that we'd really need something like a Matrioshka brain to predict consequences of changes in the near to far future.

So, ultimately, it's a high stakes high risk gamble. Geoengineering would be humanity's biggest gamble with least chances of winning. If there is any opportunity for us to do something else, we should avoid it. But as a last hurrah, why not? Do or die, sure. But I'd still prefer a Mad Max future to it, at least it's a future.

I'm surprised you guys never mentioned the alternative in metamaterials. Basically, these materials reflect heat directly into space by shifting to a frequency that the atmosphere won't block. This is actually the basis of ancient ice houses in the desert which would turn water into ice overnight by literally beating the heat into space, but these new materials can achieve that effect during the day. If you were to coat every roof in the world with these materials then the Heat Of The Sun Won't radiates into people's homes. It would reflect off into space. That would keep homes cooler, significantly cooler, in the summer time. Of course, it also means reflecting heat during the winter time, but that's the trade-off. More importantly, these metamaterials can make solar panels operate cool. The reason why solar panels have only a few Decades of life is because the heat they are exposed to causes cumulative damage over time. By preventing the build-up of heat while exposed directly to the Sun you allow the solar panels to operate longer thus reducing their overall cost.

I don't really like the idea of people saying the ice and snow in the North and South poles "reflect" sunlight, because of a few reasons.

Firstly, their location. The poles are so close to being parallel to the direction of sunlight that they don't reflect much.

Also the areas that gets hit by sunlight more are areas between Tropic of Cancer and Tropic of Capricorn, because these areas have more surface area and are facing more perpendicular to the sunlight.

Secondly, their size. The size is so tiny, they cannot do much. You can Google search an image of the earth (with the correct axis/tilt) and see that the pole that is facing the sun, half of it is not facing the sun. Then if you look at the othe pole that's not facing the sun, most of it is not facing to sun.

In my opinion, I would say that they don't reflect, but rather deflect. But even still, they are not facing directly enough or large enough to deflect much sunlight, and with the effects of global warming their size will continue to decrease, so their ability will decrease as well.

Whether or not you think that climate change is man made we obviously need to wean ourselves off fossil fuels because there is only so much natural gas and oil in the ground. Solar and wind are possible alternatives but right now are just not very practical (very expensive, not able to be transported, etc.) but I would say the best energy to switch to is nuclear energy. Nuclear energy produces more energy per unit than fossil fuels or wind and solar and also makes significantly less waste than other energy sources. Disasters are much more avoidable with better safety measures and also using elements besides uranium like thorium. I would say Nuclear energy is the "greenest energy" because what most people don't realize is that the precious metal for solar panels comes from massive, environmentally devastating strip mines in places like south Africa and south east Asia and is itself unrenewable but people are able to ignore that because it is not in their home country, so therefore it is not their problem. Overall, Nuclear is by far the best option.

Radical? You mean more radical. The proposed solutions to climate change are already radical. Think I'm being hyperbolic? If you actually want to reduce CO2 emissions to a meaningful amount, we'd have to give up on each of us having a car (even electric), a computer, or a smartphone. I don't see people doing that any time soon. Manufacture of a gasoline-fueled car, for instance, produces half of the CO2 emissions that will be generated over its lifespan. You cannot propose that we "do something" about climate change without it being radical. Despite what organizations whose existence depends on the authenticity of climate alarmism may tell you, there are many reasons to be at least a little skeptical of them. For that reason, any radical proposal's risks far outweigh the potential "gains". We might be deciding to geoengineer to fix problems that were never problems in the first place.

People think C02 plays a massive role in global warming, It doesn't, as a matter of fact, C02 isn't the worst greenhouse gas (actually the best when compared to the effects of others) nor is it the only greenhouse gas in our atmosphere. I mean seriously, I bet most of you don't even know that Ozone is actually a greenhouse gas, yet it protects life from the harmful radiation from the sun. Methane and nitrous oxide trap a vast amount more heat than co2 ever will. Co2 does NOT play a significant role in the heating of the planet. If this planet were to suffer from a catastrophic heating event in the NEAR future, the culprits would more likely be spikes in Methane and Nitrous Oxide than it would be Co2. We know this because through geological history there have been times the earths atmosphere had a higher c02 count then it does now but the planet had colder temperatures. There's also been times where the average temperature was a lot higher then it is now with almost 0% co2 present in the atmosphere. So to draw a direct correlation between co2 and the heating of the planet is just blatantly wrong. This is a natural cycle, the planet goes through heating and cooling periods, we see plenty of evidence for this in the geological record. Nothing we do is going to change that fact. If all humans died right now, the earth would continue to warm, and then in about another 80 thousand years or so, it will cool back down as it enter into another glaciation period. Sorry but humans do not have as much of an impact on the temperature as people would lead you to believe. No science for it, No evidence for it, there's just nothing to show the opposite to be true.

*Also I'm not saying to believe me on this, this is all published scientific data that I encourage you all, especially those that have a passion to help the environment, to go look at. My hopes are it will shift the attention from the things we cant truly control or change (at least not yet), to the more immediate things and the things we can control and change.

We should be talking about our waste, and how we plan on properly disposing of it. Its time to stop looking at the temperature of the planet, which by the way, is affected by a myriad of different variables, most of which we have no control over in the slightest, and start looking towards the things we can have an impact on. People want to talk about climate change but they always go straight to global warming, and the ice caps. Well here's another fun fact for you, the planets sea levels naturally rise and fall as well. Doggerland (an actual place that used to connect the UK and Ireland, as well as the Nordic countries, with mainland Europe) used to be above sea level. Many cities in Rome were above sea level and then sunk below it in the span of a couple generations. I'm no historian, but I'm fairly certain Rome wasn't an industrialized civilization, yet they still had to deal with the same problems that we are dealing with 1000 years later. These things happen over the course of geological time, and actually pretty frequently. My point here is, stop focusing on the things we cant control, rising sea levels, temperature changes, things that have been happening for millions of years. They were happening long before humans were around and they're going to happen long after. The earth and life, will be perfectly fine. This past year and the global quarantine because of Covid has shown so. Within months, animals were moving back in to territory used by humans, nature was reclaiming many installations built by humans. THE EARTH AND LIFE WILL BE JUST FINE. WE need to focus on the things that we can control, like waste, deforestation, conservation and preservation. Not worrying about the ice caps and the sea levels. Even if humanity somehow were to take ALL of the carbon out of the atmosphere in the next 24 hours, the ice caps will still melt 100 years from now. There is no stopping it, there's only expediating it or slowing it, but there is no stopping it.

Im hesitant to think we'll have a temperature shock that drastic. Maybe 20 years. The most potent greenhouse gas by a large margin is water. The equations for global warming potential factor in atmospheric lifetime which is impossible for H2O so it's never considered. H2O concentration is dependent on an equilibrium with the oceans (and terrestrial water sources) that is dependent on ions in the ocean and temperature. CO2 is the most potent greenhouse gas we can directly effect. If temperatures increase, water in the atmosphere increases and we get a positive feedback loop which is why small CO2 increases can have drastic effects over several years.

If we quit seeding the atmosphere, it's very likely that we'll see temperatures rise, but it'll take a while for that feedback loop to kick in. If we wait long enough to allow the poles to re-ice, it might mitigate a lot of that positive feedback loop and can slow down the temperature shock. We have to do some form of CO2 scrubbing as well, but still... even if we reforest the entire earth, we still don't win this game. We have to store carbon somewhere else since we pumped out from underground and cut down biomass.

There is no easy solution to this at all

I actually thought this was a pretty bad idea, not Geo-engineering in general but stratospheric aerosol injection, because
1) All the SO2 in the atmosphere would lead to formation of large amount of sulphuric acid in the atmosphere which would rain down and enter the drinking water system like rivers, lakes, ponds, etc, make oceans acidic (if carbonic acid like he said in the video makes oceans acidic, I suppose sulphuric ought to make a larger difference, though I do realize that concentration makes a difference but still), also it might kill of a large amount of plant life which is one of the most efficient way we have right now of getting rid of CO2.
2) Another point is that such a cover blocking of the sun would lead to massive reduction in vitamin D levels all over the world (before you say "pills", well not every country would be able to afford it and also I think that pills might have a lesser effect on increasing vit. D levels in the body than natural regular exposure to the sun). Vitamin D deficiency already causes a large amount of problems in a large number of people all over the world, this would only make it worse.
3) A lot of bird life might be tremendously affected by this causing a massive imbalance in the food chain.

It feels like just yesterday Kurzgesagt released a video apologizing for creating of two videos that had a strong emotional plea. I feel like they've fallen back into that mentality, especially with that last statement. Both this video and the previous climate change video have felt more like a call to action and less of a matter-of-fact, informational videos. While I personally am all for means of stopping and reversing climate change, this video feels like it was meant to scare the viewer and less to inform the viewer. Even the title feels like click-bate.

Also, correct me if I'm wrong, but pumping large amount of sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere could result in an increase in acid rain production. The SO2 gas would have to travel somewhere and that somewhere is eventually down through the troposphere where it would mix with clouds and eventually fall back to the earth as acid rain. If these statements are correct, then I am absolutely shocked that it wasn't mentioned in this video as this was a large portion of Kurzgesagt's argument.

There's other less invasive solutions to geoengineering including nightsky cooling. TL;DR the atmosphere is transparent to specific wavelengths of light, thus we take waste heat (from cooling systems or ambient heat) and radiate it out to space at those specific wavelengths we can dump heat to space slowing down global heating.

It's the same concept that spacecraft use for thermal management. And these nightsky cooling panels already reflect sunlight and can be installed on rooftops just like normal photovoltaic panels.

We could try taking gasses like CO2 out of our atmosphere and use it in either ship construction, such as using carbonite, or try transporting it to mars if we make a large enough ship. Then Mars would start to heat up, and we could start colonizing it.

The main problem with this solution is that we would need to make something like a tanker for space and make something like a space elevator or space pipeline to transport the CO2 and other gases. We would also need to find a way to transport the gasses the tanker would bring to Mar's surface, which could be done by a space elevator/pipeline again, or just crashing the ship.

This solution give the benefit of making Mars much more inhabitable, encouraging space to be explored, reducing greenhouse gasses on Earth, it would become profitable eventually because of things like mining and tourism, and also cheaper access to space. The problems would be the large cost initially, a large amount of this needs to be built from scratch, greenhouse gas collectors might be hard to set up where they need to be set up, and it is a multi-space agency project and some may only have national intrest that harm everyone else.

What about the idea of engineering life-forms that are capable of doing much of this processing for us? Plants are already amazing chemists, and malevolent as they are, the Mon Santo Corporation has done some fairly wild experiments. Most of their crop produces its own herbicide and insecticide, why couldn't we genetically engineer a crop that produces ozone or is two or three times as efficient at scrubbing carbon from the atmosphere?

Not only could this significantly affect our own planet, but it could also be used to colonize other planets. Engineering more durable plants that can survive the harsh conditions of a less-than-hospitable world long enough to alter the composition of its atmosphere could limit the amount of heavy equipment that we would need to bring over for such a task.

Climate change is a natural phenomenon, and it's not a rising threat, it comes in waves. The IPCC data itself proves that. Renewables (like solar and wind energy), does more damage to the environment than fossil energy, and is economically unsustainable.

Humanity ecological struggles can be solved this way:

1 - Investment in Nuclear Thorium Energy: It's clean and nuclear waste is minimal and more stable.

2 - Plastic reduction technologies: Ways to remove waste plastic from the environment (plastic islands in the ocean for example) are paramount for the stabilization of part of the world wildlife.

3 - Industrial byproduct neutralization: Some factories around the world (most of them in china and india) throw chemical waste and factory byproducts in the atmosphere, jungles and rivers. If technologies to neutralize the waste is applied, the stuff we throw in the wild will do no harm to the environment, thus, making the human action harmless to the environment.

We don't need geoengineering to save the planet, it probably will destroy it completely. Better solutions are much simpler than that.

I'm not a climate denier, or whatever the term is now, but I don't believe that manmade climate change is occurring on the scale that demoncrats claim. The Earth has went through hot and cold changes, on a drastic level, numerous times throughout its history and you can view the trends. The trends show that while we have had a slight impact, it is within the same historical trends and we're due for a cold swing probably within the next 150-200 years. The average temp isn't even predicted to increase half a degree in the next 100 years. I don't want to say it is a hoax because it is naïve to think we don't contribute negatively to the climate, but we have been hearing about thee doomsday prophecies for a 100 years now and nothing has gotten worse. It's true, the trends clearly show we're following Earths natural climate cycle.

There are four places that excess atmospheric carbon can go:
1. The ocean absorbs it - acidifying the ocean and causing some seriously unpleasant shit.
2. It stays in the atmosphere - we all know why that's a problem.
3. Deep well injection - pump it deep into the Earth and pretend it doesn't exist. Slow, expensive and as asinine as sweeping dust under the rug.
4. Regenerative agriculture - stop feeding corn to ruminant animals that can't digest it anyway, restore that corn land to pasture and graze the ruminants on the pastures (which they CAN digest). The soil will absorb massive amounts of carbon from the atmosphere AND it will dramatically reduce soil erosion, increase soil fertility and stabilize the water cycle, all at the same time. It's such a no brainer that we are of course fighting against it tooth and nail 🤨
